text: You punk! Hey, police! Don't move! It took you guys long enough! This dude's out of his mind! Shut up! Sold my grandson pills that were laced with fentanyl! I want you to arrest him right now! Okay, we can talk about that, but first you gotta put down that gun! Sir, drop your weapon now! But if you don't come right now, I'm gonna finish it. We're gonna arrest him. But first you gotta give me this gun. Hands behind your back. What the hell? I didn't do anything! Go with it. I'm trying to save your life. Are you out of your mind? You just held him at gunpoint. That's against the law. I know the law. Oh. I'm a retired cop. We arrested a retired sergeant this morning, and he claims that this guy sold his grandson drugs laced with fentanyl. Which I'm sure the detective on the case will be happy to know. He says the detective knows it's this guy. He just hasn't done anything. Detective O'Leary. What do you need, Sarge? My team's looking into a rash of fentanyl overdoses in the precinct. I'd like to ask you a few questions about the death of Vince Valucci. No disrespect, boss, but I don't really appreciate you guys coming in here and poking your nose in my case. Somebody was already here? Your wife was here an hour ago. She grilled me on my case. You may want to remind her how things work around here. You want to know what's going on? Go home and ask your wife. What were you thinking, grilling Detective O'Leary? I asked her a couple questions. You would have done the same thing. I would have never gone over a sergeant's head and questioned a detective on their handling of a case. Are you pulling rank on me? You are a patrol officer. You are not a detective. You made a promise to Sam. You gotta stop doing that. Doing what? Making promises that you can't deliver. Sam deserves justice for his grandson. I am sure he does, but I don't even know the guy. If you would have met him, you would have done the same thing. I did look into the overdose like you asked me, but I did it because it was good intel. Not because I made a promise to a grieving man. Well, then, what did you think? I think we may be able to tie this dealer to numerous other deaths. Then what the hell are we fighting about? Because I was going to ask Detective O'Leary to open a joint investigation, but since you pissed her off, that's not going to happen. Well, we don't even need her. She already admitted she's confident Marco sold the drugs. She just doesn't have enough evidence to arrest him. What does she have? Text messages on the victim's phone asking to score from Marco. You have his information? Yeah. I even met him. You know, if you find anything? Yeah, you got anything that's not in the case? Hey, man. This ain't that kind of place. I got cash. Help me out? Okay. Get the hell out of here. Whoa, man. If you ever think about coming back, I'll kill you. I'm not looking for any trouble. I just want to score. And I said I don't do that. Police! Don't move! Yo, man, I was just defending myself. This addict was trying to rob the register. Police. Hands behind your back. You're under arrest. You a cop? Some guy pulled a gun out on me this week. I got to defend myself, but I swear I don't sell no drugs. There's product back here in plain view. I suggest you start telling the truth. We arrested Marco and two men who were supplying fentanyl to multiple dealers across the city. That's wonderful. Marco wrote a letter to the DA where he admitted to selling Vince the drugs. And he requested the DA drop all charges against you. What does that mean? It means you're free to go. Really? That's damn good police work.

chapters.headline: Confrontation with Police and Drug Dealer
chapters.summary: A tense scene unfolds where a grandfather confronts a dealer accused of selling dangerous drugs to his grandson, prompting the police to intervene amid threats and accusations.
